title: What are the most important concepts in art? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m unsure of the question. “Most important” would imply a single concept but then “concepts” follows.Do we argue down to one, or let everyone have their own?As an artist and as a person with a career in arts education (Art History and public school general arts education), I’ve stayed awake at night with this question.That in itself does not give me license to answer perhaps. So I’ll share my thoughts and leave the real answers to those who have already posted.It seems to me that art has at its root an obsessive idea in the mind of an individual. The idea is a combination of accreted sensory experience that is interpreted and stored in the individual. It’s not factual but situational. It’s not concrete but fluid and dynamic. The idea percolates through the mind until the individual needs to express it.That requires materials and some modicum of courage, skill, or both. The resulting material expression (what we call “art”) is only that- a material expression and it may or may not be accurate. Artists usually see all the things they need to correct while the audience sees the marks they made. I have arrived at this point from a couple of sources. The first is a sensory awareness of “me” and how I relate to the “rest” which is everything else. Asking, “where am I?” implies a relation to “that which is around me” and that includes a canvas, brushes and palette in the simplest of terms. (It’s much more comprehensive than that.) Knowing where I am in space in time is essential, I believe in being able to get paint to canvas. Maybe it’s just me. The other source is the mechanism by which an idea with no material substance is translated into material expression. The closest I can come is to recognize that the paint on my brush represents an aspect of my idea. And once that paint is applied, it is at once a representation of my idea, a material fact in and of itself, and a trigger for the viewer. the first viewer is me, and I evaluate what I see against what I have as an idea. Everything changes and the next stroke goes down on the basis of the change. That process is summed up in the term “metaphor”. It’s where I mostly live with my art production. Again, maybe it’s just me. I would offer that without an active ideation process ongoing in an individual, art would not be possible- at least in a form we recognize currently as art.
